word.entryDescription: to make unskilled or experimental efforts at repair
word.entryExample: John is tinkering around with the engine.

word.entryDescription: a useful piece of advice
word.entryExample: Thanks very much for the exam tips.

word.entryDescription: marks left on the ground by a moving vehicle
word.entryExample: The evidence a forensic team collects at a crime scene can include samples of different substances, as well as copies or photographs of fingerprints, footprints or tyre tracks and even handwriting.

word.entryDescription: feeling sleepy or not having much energy
word.entryExample: I didn't go on the trip because I was very tired.

word.entryDescription: the name of a book, story, film, etc
word.entryExample: Do you know the title of this story?

word.entryDescription: used to say how true something is or how great an effect it has
word.entryExample: Tell me to what extent of all trips are job-related travel.

word.entryDescription: to be later than planned
word.entryExample: Unfortunately the ferry was delayed a lot, because of the bad weather.

word.entry: to be on the point of
word.entryDescription: to be going to do something very soon
word.entryExample: I'm on the point of finishing my catering course.

word.entryDescription: a piece of bread you heat until it is brown and dry
word.entryExample: Do you want some toast for breakfast?

word.entryDescription: a piece of equipment you use to make toast
word.entryExample: Kerry has to make some toast in the toaster.

word.entryDescription: on the present day
word.entryExample: It's my birthday today!

word.entryDescription: one of five small parts of your body on the end of your foot
word.entryExample: We have ten fingers and ten toes.

word.entryDescription: with each other
word.entryExample: Let's go on holiday together!

word.entryDescription: (WC – water closet) a small room with a large bowl in it that you use to get rid of waste from your body
word.entryExample: There's a living room, a very small kitchen, a dining room, a toilet and bathroom and two bedrooms.

word.entryDescription: a round soft red fruit with lots of seeds, which is used as a vegetable
word.entryExample: This tomato soup is delicious.

word.entryDescription: on the day after today
word.entryExample: How about going to the beach tomorrow?

word.entryDescription: more than is acceptable, suitable or possible
word.entryExample: This car is too slow, let's take the train.

word.entryDescription: also (used at the end of a sentence)
word.entryExample: He loved football and he could play very well. His PE teacher saw that he could run very well, too.

word.entryDescription: something that helps you to do a particular activity
word.entryExample: Not long ago, we humans thought we were the only creatures to make and use tools, but we were wrong.

word.entryDescription: a small hard part inside your mouth which you use for biting
word.entryExample: The baby has a new tooth.

word.entryDescription: a pain in your tooth
word.entryExample: She's got a very bad toothache.

word.entryDescription: the highest part
word.entryExample: The view from the top of the mountain was amazing.

word.entryDescription: a piece of clothing worn on the upper part of the body
word.entryExample: My brother doesn't like tight tops, so he usually wears a baggy jumper.

word.entryDescription: the highest level in a building
word.entryExample: My bedroom is on the top floor of my house.

word.entryDescription: to increase the amount of something to the level you want or need
word.entryExample: When you top up your card, you touch the travel card reader twice with your card.

word.entryDescription: a subject that someone talks, writes or learns about
word.entryExample: Sarah continues the topic, she says Jake reminds her of herself.

word.entryDescription: a small light that is held in the hand and usually gets its power from batteries
word.entryExample: Did you take the torch in your bag?

word.entryDescription: (plural 'tornadoes') an extremely violent weather event in which a fast-spinning column of air forms between a cloud and the land
word.entryExample: Tornadoes are faster than hurricanes.

word.entryDescription: a small animal with a hard shell that moves slowly
word.entryExample: This tortoise is the slowest.
Some volcanoes are active, others are totally extinct.

word.entryDescription: to feel something with your hand
word.entryExample: Can you touch your toes?

word.entryDescription: a journey on which you visit a number of places or sights
word.entryExample: I'm planning my third tour around the world, in a balloon!

word.entryDescription: to travel around to perform, advertise something, etc
word.entryExample: The Beatles also toured widely, starting off in Sweden and then going to the USA.

word.entryDescription: a person who provides assistance, information to people on organized tours
word.entryExample: The tour guides are happy to show you the rainforest by boat, but first you must learn to paddle a kayak.

word.entryDescription: a sports competition in which players compete against each other in a series of games until there is one winner
word.entryExample: Did Harry meet Roger Federer at the tennis tournament?

word.entryDescription: in the direction of
word.entryExample: Turn right and walk towards the church.

word.entryDescription: a piece of cloth you use to dry yourself when you are wet
word.entryExample: We're going to the beach, so take your towel.

word.entryDescription: a tall narrow structure
word.entryExample: The Eiffel Tower is the most famous building in Paris.
An army of blue attendants swarmed behind us to close the towering metal gates.

word.entryDescription: a large area where people live and work
word.entryExample: A town is smaller than a city.

word.entryDescription: a terraced house
word.entryExample: I think the town houses are new because they look modern and freshly painted.

word.entryDescription: a box you keep toys in
word.entryExample: What's in your toybox?

word.entryDescription: a prepared or marked surface on which racing takes place
word.entryExample: My brother is running on track 1.

word.entryDescription: a sports suit consisting of matching jacket and trousers
word.entryExample: The athletes took off their tracksuits before the race.

word.entryDescription: a pair of loose sports trousers that are a part of a tracksuit (a sports suit consisting of matching jacket and trousers)
word.entryExample: My skinny jeans aren't very comfortable. I prefer tracksuit bottoms.

word.entryDescription: the activity of buying, selling or exchanging goods or services
word.entryExample: Why is Panama such an important area for trade?

word.entryDescription: a way of behaving, or doing something that has been used by the people in a particular group (family, society, etc.) for a long time
word.entryExample: The word Origami comes from 'ori', which means folding and 'kami', which means paper and there is a long tradition of it in Japan.

word.entryDescription: being part of the ways, behaviour and customs of a particular group of people that have continued for a long time
word.entryExample: Kyoto remains one of the most beautiful and traditional parts of Japan.

word.entryDescription: all the vehicles moving on the road
word.entryExample: There isn't much traffic where we live.

word.entryDescription: a long line of slow-moving traffic
word.entryExample: I'm sorry my bus was delayed by this really long traffic jam.
